Omegamon_X

http://www.guardian.co.uk/uk/2008/aug/30/ukcrime1
 
 The gun shown here, a Webley, is up for sale in London for £150, one of hundreds of such weapons that are easily and cheaply available on the streets of the UK's big cities, a Guardian investigation can reveal.
 
 The variety of weapons on offer in Britain is extensive and includes machine guns and shotguns, as well as pistols and converted replicas. A source close to the trade in illegal weapons contacted by the Guardian listed a menu of firearms that are available on the streets of the capital.
 
 "You can get a clean [unused] 9mm automatic for £1,500, a Glock for a couple of grand and you can even make an order for a couple of MAC-10s," he said. "Or you can get a little sawn-off for £150. They're easy enough to get hold of. You'll find one in any poverty area, every estate in London, and it's even easier in Manchester, where there are areas where the police don't go.
 
 "People who use shotguns tend to be lower down the pecking order. There is less use of sawn-off or full length shotguns, and if a criminal wants street cred, he wants a self-loading pistol, a MAC-10 or an Uzi submachine gun."
 
 This week a man who ran a "factory" for converting replica weapons into working guns was jailed for life. Police believe the products of Grant Wilkinson's workshops were used in more than 50 shootings, including eight murders. His speciality was turning legally purchased MAC-10s into weapons that could fire live rounds, an increasingly common practice.
 
 According to David Dyson, a leading firearms consultant, it is possible to learn through the internet how to make a firearm, given a degree of skill, and converted deactivated weapons also feature in shootings.
 
 But it is the arrival of eastern European weapons that, alongside a homegrown industry in converting them, has contributed to the firearms glut. "There has been an influx from eastern Europe and particularly from Poland, and there are also a lot coming in from people who have served in Afghanistan and Iraq," said the source. "In Liverpool docks, you can put in an order for 10 guns and some grenades and they'll say OK and two weeks later, they will be there - and they are straight goers."
 
 According to Dyson, the latest "weapon of choice" is a Russian 8mm Baikal self-defence pistol, originally used for firing CS gas. "They are legally sold in Germany and won't fire a bullet but they can be converted by removing the partially blocked barrel, and replacing it with a rifled barrel," he said. "After other small alterations, it can then fire 9mm bulleted ammunition. The replacement barrel is longer than the original, and is threaded so that it will accept a silencer, which is commonly sold as part of the package.
 
 "There are hundreds of these floating around and hundreds have been seized," he said. "They look the part as they are based on the Russian military Makarov pistol. If you are a 20-year-old drug dealer and you want a gun, that is what you will get and it will cost about £1,000 to £1,500."
 
 "The trends in firearms are driven by the suppliers," said Dyson. "About two years ago, a supplier brought back hundreds of German-made revolvers, blank-firing pistols which can be bought legally in Germany. They were then converted and new cylinders made. They could then be sold for £700 to £800 when the supplier would have bought them for 60 and spent about £30 on converting them."
 
 Home Office data shows that gun crime is up since last year, despite the recent doubling of sentences for possessing or supplying firearms. There were 9,803 firearms offences in England and Wales in the year to March 2008 with most in London, Manchester and the West Midlands.
 
 Most buyers are involved with drug dealing, the source said. Some are used to rob other dealers in crimes that go unreported, others are used as protection while a deal is under way. "Someone will have a tool and there is always one guy in a posse willing to use it. They will have one guy who doesn't give a ####.
 
 "Everyone wants to be a gangster now, mainly the kids. You have five or six in a little crew and one of them will be carrying. They want handguns - shotguns are too big and bulky. The sawn-off doesn't look so good but use a machine gun and you get known as a heavy guy. They have them just to be a chap on the street, to pose. Some of them walk around all day with a .38. It's 16-year-olds at it and it's getting like America, silly as it sounds."
 
 In terms of nationalities, the influx of eastern European criminals has changed the balance of power. "Who's using the guns? The [Jamaican] Yardies' value for life was so minimal that they thought nothing of killing people," said the source. "We don't like them, they have no moral code. But it's the Russians and the Polish and Albanians around now. They are bullies. They want to take over the flesh business. The Russians are cold-hearted ####ers. What they have been doing is following the card boys [who put cards advertising prostitutes in phone booths in central London] and then taking the girls hostage, armed if need be."
 
 Detective Chief Inspector Colin Sutton, who has investigated some of London's most high profile shooting murders, said he believed the age of offenders was getting younger, and sometimes guns seemed to be used for the slightest reason.
 
 "Playground squabbles are now being settled with guns," he said. "And drug dealers are taking a policy decision to get youngsters to carry guns."
 
 He said guns could be purchased for a few hundred pounds in many parts of London. "You can hire a gun for a period and, if the gun has already been used for a murder, the going rate comes down."
 
 While the conviction of Wilkinson was seen as a breakthrough, it is accepted that with the increased traffic between Britain and eastern Europe, stemming the flow of weapons remains an almost impossible task.
 
 "Guns are always available," said Dyson. "You can go to the former Soviet Union, or countries with less stringent regulations than ours, and although British Customs have their successes, many guns appear to be smuggled into the UK."
 
 Amnesties for people to hand over weapons are greeted with scepticism by criminals. "The gun amnesties are meaningless," the source said. "All you get handed in are guns from boys who wanted to be gangsters and then got a job or someone whose mother found it in their bedroom. If I had a gun, I wouldn't take part because, if I got pulled, what would I say - 'Oh, I'm just on my way to the amnesty.' Also if it gets out that you've given in your tool, people will think you're a wrong 'un."
 
 Few professional criminals would keep guns on their premises. "Only silly people keep it in their homes. Normally, you have a 'keeper' a couple of miles away and some of them have been at it for 20 years. It's best to have an old fellow with no previous or a woman. You keep the ammunition separate because you'll get a much heavier sentence if you have them together."
 
 When guns are moved from place to place, a young woman is often used as the courier because there is less risk of her being stopped and searched.
 
 What is not in dispute is the devastating effect that the casual use of a gun over a minor argument can have on dozens of people. In December 2006, Sean "Stretch" Jenkins, 36, an amiable, 6ft 8in window-cleaner from south London, was shot dead at a party in Carshalton. His killer was a cocaine dealer called Joseph Greenland, a volatile man with a quick temper, who had apparently taken offence at something Jenkins said. The men had earlier been at a boxing night at Caesar's in Streatham, where there had been some fighting outside the ring. Greenland had left the party, driven home in his Range Rover, picked up a gun and returned to kill Jenkins in front of at least five witnesses, who were warned not to talk.
 
 None of the immediate witnesses gave evidence against Greenland, who had a reputation for threatening to "annihilate" anyone who crossed him, but there were traces of his DNA on a cigarette end and a wine glass at the party and his bragging about the shooting was to be his downfall. His recourse to a gun, for no other reason than some perceived slight, left Jenkins's six-year-old son without a father and saddened a wide network of friends and family. Greenland was jailed for life last week and will have to serve 30 years before he can be considered for parole.
 
 "We got what we wanted," said the victim's mother, Maureen Jenkins, of the verdict and sentence last month. "I went to the cemetery and said, 'Well, boy, I can put you to rest'."
 
 The detectives investigating the killing and the prosecution team that secured Greenland's conviction were "marvellous", she said. "I shed tears every day and I probably will till the day I die. Why do these people have to kill for nothing? If they want to kill people, why don't they join the army? You don't ever think a shooting will happen in your life. It's all down to guns, just guns."
 
 The Guardian's source said that guns were becoming a first rather than a last recourse. "A gun used to be used as a mediator; now everything is revolved with a gun. It's brought the heat on everyone. Before you would get a two [years jail sentence], now it's a five. It's getting like the US now, like The Wire. It's like a prediction of what will happen here. I think they all think they're playing Grand Theft Auto. It's madness out there."
 
 Well I guess that nationwide handgun ban is doing the trick then.

post_info.post_title: Firearms: cheap, easy to get and on a street near you

GazzaElliott
I think it shows it's having an effect. You can't pick up a gun for £40 ($80) in this country....
Ethmi

I think it shows it's having an effect. You can't pick up a gun for £40 ($80) in this country....

 
 Wow! I never knew there was a correlation between prices and crime rates was positive! Prices go up, crime rates go up. This argument helps us more than it helps you.
smiley

Wow! I never knew there was a correlation between prices and crime rates was positive! Prices go up, crime rates go up. This argument helps us more than it helps you.

 Please explain how you came up with this correlation.
Ethmi

Please explain how you came up with this correlation.

 
 Try to follow me for once. Mega showed high crime rates. Gazza stated that guns are expensive. They both claimed that this was result of the ban on handguns. Evidently, the ban didn't work because Mega's article stated that guns can be illegally bought for £150. Do I need to explain further, or did you get it the first time?
Shooterandproud
Wow, I paid more for my skirmish-grade airsoft gun.
GazzaElliott

Try to follow me for once. Mega showed high crime rates.

 
 No, Mega posted a long editorial from the guardian which was written after the police arrested the owner of a conversion factory. It's interesting that they claim the gun crimes stats have gone up, when all the sources I've seen show that violent gun crime has gone down. That's the guardian for you. It doesn't show that we have high crime rates whichever stats you accept.
 
 
Gazza stated that guns are expensive.
 
 
 Not expensive enough, but enough to put them out of the range of small time punks. Guns appear to be the preserve of the drugs and organised crime arenas at the moment.
 
 
They both claimed that this was result of the ban on handguns.
 
 
 Actually, Mega didn't make any claims. He just reposted an editorial.
 
 
Evidently, the ban didn't work because Mega's article stated that guns can be illegally bought for £150.

 
 When has anyone claimed that banning firearms makes them impossible to get hold of? I could make one if I wanted.... It wouldn't be very good, but it still means there's a supply. The point is that banning guns pushes the price up and reduces the avaliability of guns to the criminal classes, thus only the criminals with a lot of money will own them. Given that these criminals are more interested in the top levels of the drug trade and are more worried about each other, rather than knocking off a few ordinary people for thier wallets, society is safer as a whole.
Omegamon_X

Not expensive enough, but enough to put them out of the range of small time punks.

 
 Going by your papers it would seem that even small time punks have enough funding to buy handguns.
 
 
When has anyone claimed that banning firearms makes them impossible to get hold of?

 
 The claim is made anytime a person says that this, that, or the other ban will help save lives and stop criminals. They imply that the new law will play some part in ending crime, not hampering it but ending it.
 
 Now if this isn't the case then the claim should be that the law will make it harder for the criminal to get a gun and kill you with it, which basically states that you're still going to be murdered, it'll just be more of an inconvenience for the criminal first.
 
 
The point is that banning guns pushes the price up and reduces the avaliability of guns to the criminal classes,

 
 Call me strange if you want, but I thought the entire point of banning something was to make it completely inaccessible. We banned new machineguns from civilian ownership in 1986, nobody can get a new P90 through legal channels even if they're willing to pay $10,000 for it.
 
 In the 1920s we banned alcoholic beverages, the idea was that the ban would end alcoholic consumption, not establish a caste system where only the rich could be drunk.
 
 
Given that these criminals are more interested in the top levels of the drug trade and are more worried about each other, rather than knocking off a few ordinary people for thier wallets, society is safer as a whole.

 
 So lemme see if I can get this straight. The criminals have real guns and can kill innocent people in a crossfire, you regular people are unarmed and can't do anything if a gun is waved in your face, and you claim that society is safer this way; with the bad guys armed and the innocent naked and vulnerable.
GazzaElliott

Going by your papers it would seem that even small time punks have enough funding to buy handguns.

 
 Well, that's obviously not the case given that small time punks aren't running around with guns....
 
 
The claim is made anytime a person says that this, that, or the other ban will help save lives and stop criminals. They imply that the new law will play some part in ending crime, not hampering it but ending it.

 
 I never made that claim. It's the ultimate aim of a ban, but anyone with a brain knows that it'll be impossible to achieve outside of a dictatorship.
 
 
Now if this isn't the case then the claim should be that the law will make it harder for the criminal to get a gun and kill you with it, which basically states that you're still going to be murdered, it'll just be more of an inconvenience for the criminal first.

 
 No... Just because some criminals have the ability to get hold of guns doesn't mean that you're going to be murdered. You seem very scared of being attacked. The point is that the practical effect of a ban is that it keeps the guns out of the hands of low level thugs, and thus makes it much less likely for you to be attacked and murdered with a gun.
 
 
Call me strange if you want, but I thought the entire point of banning something was to make it completely inaccessible. We banned new machineguns from civilian ownership in 1986, nobody can get a new P90 through legal channels even if they're willing to pay $10,000 for it.

 
 The emphasis is the word legally. In this country you can't get handguns legally, even if you're willing to pay £5,000. You have to obtain it illegally. I don't know what the going prices are for illegal arms in the US.
 
 
In the 1920s we banned alcoholic beverages, the idea was that the ban would end alcoholic consumption, not establish a caste system where only the rich could be drunk.

 
 What was the effect? Alcohol became confined to the top of the tree where the money was (ignoring basement stills for the moment). In crime terms, this is the same with a ban on guns. The guns become confined to the drug running gangs, and they don't go round shooting people for no reason. Not to mention that the gangs are easier to keep an eye on, than having to observe everyone.
 
 
So lemme see if I can get this straight. The criminals have real guns and can kill innocent people in a crossfire, you regular people are unarmed and can't do anything if a gun is waved in your face, and you claim that society is safer this way; with the bad guys armed and the innocent naked and vulnerable. 

 
 No.... What I said is that people are safer because you are unlikely to be attacked by someone with a gun, thus you not having one becomes irrelevant. Drug gangs, by thier very nature, avoid populated areas when traffiking large quantities in order to protect themselves. You seem to think that life is like the movies, and any second everyone's going to wip out Ingrams and start blazing at each other. It has happened, but it's very rare.
Omegamon_X

Well, that's obviously not the case given that small time punks aren't running around with guns....

 
 Do you have any proof to back up this statement?
 
 
I never made that claim. It's the ultimate aim of a ban, but anyone with a brain knows that it'll be impossible to achieve outside of a dictatorship.

 
 So now you're saying that the only way to be free of violent crime is to live under an oppressive dictatorship, something like Nazi Germany or Fascist Italy?
 
 That's quite a situation right there, between a rock and a hard place. You can either have armed criminals or you can be under the thumb of a dictator and have no rights at all. Makes you wonder which is worse.
 
 
No... Just because some criminals have the ability to get hold of guns doesn't mean that you're going to be murdered.

 
 It doesn't mean that you won't either, although it does mean that you can be taken advantage of and have the choice of either compliance or death. "Some" criminals aren't getting guns according to your papers, many are still armed and continuing to be armed despite your laws. To me that says that something is very wrong over in your country.
 
 I don't get it, you've implemented this system where there's absolutely no legal excuse for being in possession of a handgun, the police have more powers regarding stops, searches and seizures, and you still can't stomp out armed criminals. What exactly is going wrong over there?
 
 
The point is that the practical effect of a ban is that it keeps the guns out of the hands of low level thugs, and thus makes it much less likely for you to be attacked and murdered with a gun.

 
 I've yet to see any tangible proof of this statement.
 
 
The emphasis is the word legally. In this country you can't get handguns legally, even if you're willing to pay £5,000. You have to obtain it illegally.

 
 Which is currently what's going on.
 
 
What was the effect?
 
 
 People started brewing bathtub gin, selling it to distributors, the booze runners were making a considerable amount of money, making them quite wealthy and powerful and influential and setting up the playing field for the death of a number of police officers who were mowed down by sudden rich crooks. Prohibition paved the way for the Roaring '20s, which was the motivation for the 1934 National Firearms Act because the illegal nature of booze drastically empowered the criminals.
 
 Why is it that nobody can seem to understand that making something illegal actually benefits criminals rather than hurting them?
 
 
No.... What I said is that people are safer because you are unlikely to be attacked by someone with a gun, thus you not having one becomes irrelevant. Drug gangs, by thier very nature, avoid populated areas when traffiking large quantities in order to protect themselves. You seem to think that life is like the movies, and any second everyone's going to wip out Ingrams and start blazing at each other. It has happened, but it's very rare.

 
 Listen to yourself dude, no matter how you try and sell it, no matter what kind of spin you put on it, you're still saying that society is safer when the criminals have exclusive access to guns and innocent people are totally cut off.
Penfold

....
 Why is it that nobody can seem to understand that making something illegal actually benefits criminals rather than hurting them? .... 

 
 
 I vote we pause here for a few minutes to contemplate the massive stupidity of this utterance.
Omegamon_X

I vote we pause here for a few minutes to contemplate the massive stupidity of this utterance.

 
 So...you're saying the existence of drug lords who have made millions of dollars from selling cocaine, isn't proof that making something illegal is empowering to criminals?
GazzaElliott

Do you have any proof to back up this statement?

 
 Personal experience. The fact that gun crime is low in this country. The fact that the number of muggings and assaults with firearms is very low, even in a place like london....
 
 
So now you're saying that the only way to be free of violent crime is to live under an oppressive dictatorship, something like Nazi Germany or Fascist Italy?

 
 I tell you what, I'll use simple words, just for you emoticon_xgood
 
 There is no way to be totally free of violent crime with human beings. All that can be done is to reduce the amount, and the threat to the average person. That doesn't mean that you have to evoke the Nazi's (You did read that bit about Nazi's and loosing arguments didn't you?). 
 
 
That's quite a situation right there, between a rock and a hard place. You can either have armed criminals or you can be under the thumb of a dictator and have no rights at all. Makes you wonder which is worse.

 
 God but you're a pessimist aren't you! We're not under a dictatorship, and we have very low levels of armed crime, even with the current spate of stabbings in London. It's therefore possible to have both.
 
 
It doesn't mean that you won't either, although it does mean that you can be taken advantage of and have the choice of either compliance or death. "Some" criminals aren't getting guns according to your papers, many are still armed and continuing to be armed despite your laws. To me that says that something is very wrong over in your country.

 
 You sound like a editorial for the Daily Mail. It is possible that someone in this country could attack me with a gun and kill me, however the odds are heavily in my favour that it won't. Given that assault with deadly weapons is rare, why should I panic about it happening? I don't think something is wrong over here, I know that some criminals are getting round the law, and that's where the police and law enforcement come in.
 
 
I don't get it, you've implemented this system where there's absolutely no legal excuse for being in possession of a handgun, the police have more powers regarding stops, searches and seizures, and you still can't stomp out armed criminals. What exactly is going wrong over there?

 
 Not enough police if you ask me. The main problem is similar to the Mafia problem you had in the US. There are organised gang traffiking guns and drugs into this country, and the police aren't keeping up. Anyway, since when has anyone been able to 'stomp out armed criminals'? That's almost impossible to do outside of a police state.
 
 
I've yet to see any tangible proof of this statement.

 
 The low level of gun crime in this country.... I think it's the American attitude towards guns as much as any legal status of said weapons that's caused the crime over there. Switzerland has proven that you can own guns and not have the sky-high crime rates that the US has.
 
 
Which is currently what's going on.

 
 Well done, you've proven you can state the obvious...
 
 
People started brewing bathtub gin, selling it to distributors, the booze runners were making a considerable amount of money, making them quite wealthy and powerful and influential and setting up the playing field for the death of a number of police officers who were mowed down by sudden rich crooks. Prohibition paved the way for the Roaring '20s, which was the motivation for the 1934 National Firearms Act because the illegal nature of booze drastically empowered the criminals.

 
 So you support legalization of everything? Interesting....
 
 
Why is it that nobody can seem to understand that making something illegal actually benefits criminals rather than hurting them?

 
 emoticon_xbangheadxbanghead:xbanghead
 
 It depends on what it is. Making murder illegal hasn't helped criminals. Making CFC's illegal hasn't helped criminals. Drugs have made some criminals rich, but they've also lead to the death of several criminals in turf wars, and what not. They've also lead to people being sent to prison for a long time. 
 
 
Listen to yourself dude, no matter how you try and sell it, no matter what kind of spin you put on it, you're still saying that society is safer when the criminals have exclusive access to guns and innocent people are totally cut off. 

 
 No... I'm saying that society is safer when petty criminals don't have access to guns. Given that guns are illegal, anyone who owns them is a de facto criminal, whether they use them for defense or for assault. Thus only criminals will have access to guns, and thus your statement is flawed by default.
Omegamon_X

Personal experience. The fact that gun crime is low in this country. The fact that the number of muggings and assaults with firearms is very low, even in a place like london....

 
 Maybe you could supply stats that show the crime rates from 1987-1997 are considerably higher than crime rates for 1998-2008.
 
 
You sound like a editorial for the Daily Mail. It is possible that someone in this country could attack me with a gun and kill me, however the odds are heavily in my favour that it won't. Given that assault with deadly weapons is rare, why should I panic about it happening?

 
 What was it, only one single case of a school shooting, which served as the basis for banning all handgun ownership over there?
 
 You guys across the pond fully embraced the "once is more than enough" mindset when it came to banning guns to stop school shootings, but the same mindset doesn't work with assaults because they're a rare occurrence and not worth the trouble? You're holding two entirely contradictory beliefs at the same time.
 
 
Not enough police if you ask me. The main problem is similar to the Mafia problem you had in the US. There are organised gang traffiking guns and drugs into this country, and the police aren't keeping up. Anyway, since when has anyone been able to 'stomp out armed criminals'? That's almost impossible to do outside of a police state.

 
 So you're really no better off than we are. It seems the only real difference is that over here a criminal has a much better chance of dying at the hands of an intended victim.
 
 
The low level of gun crime in this country.... I think it's the American attitude towards guns as much as any legal status of said weapons that's caused the crime over there. Switzerland has proven that you can own guns and not have the sky-high crime rates that the US has.

 
 They have gun ownership rates comparable with America, a more firearms-friendly culture than Britain, every adult of a certain age is issued genuine military firearms, and they still have lower crime rates than Britain. How do you explain that away? The only thing I can think of as a possible excuse is that the British are too sloppy to do it right.
 
 
Well done, you've proven you can state the obvious...

 
 And in many instances you've proven that the obvious escapes you.
 
 
So you support legalization of everything? Interesting....

 
 No I'm simply stating that making something illegal will only benefit criminals, not anyone else.
 
 
No... I'm saying that society is safer when petty criminals don't have access to guns. Given that guns are illegal, anyone who owns them is a de facto criminal, whether they use them for defense or for assault. Thus only criminals will have access to guns, and thus your statement is flawed by default.

 
 Petty criminals, drug lords, it really makes no difference because it all boils down to one thing: the criminals are still armed, the innocent people aren't, and your claim is that society is safer with this method of doing things.
 
 I don't care what rank a criminal individual has, they're all the same to me; people who knowingly and willingly break the laws to get ahead through illegal channels. Trying to explain away the differences doesn't fly with me, they're all members of the same society class; criminals. And your statement still amounts to "Criminals have guns, regular people don't, and society is safer this way".
GazzaElliott

Maybe you could supply stats that show the crime rates from 1987-1997 are considerably higher than crime rates for 1998-2008.

 
 The stats were provided on that other thread. I don't think they've changed in a few months...
 
 
What was it, only one single case of a school shooting, which served as the basis for banning all handgun ownership over there?

 
 As I recall, the Dunblaine Massacre lead to the banning of all handguns.
 
 
You guys across the pond fully embraced the "once is more than enough" mindset when it came to banning guns to stop school shootings, but the same mindset doesn't work with assaults because they're a rare occurrence and not worth the trouble? You're holding two entirely contradictory beliefs at the same time.

 
 No, I'm saying that assaults should be dealt with, but that I shouldn't be scared of someone attacking me with a gun. The number of assaults using guns is very low. Why do we need guns to defend ourselves from something that is highly unlikely to happen?
 
 
So you're really no better off than we are. It seems the only real difference is that over here a criminal has a much better chance of dying at the hands of an intended victim.

 
 Apart from the fact that your crime rates are very much higher than ours. It seems that you have a higher chance of being killed...
 
 
They have gun ownership rates comparable with America, a more firearms-friendly culture than Britain, every adult of a certain age is issued genuine military firearms, and they still have lower crime rates than Britain. How do you explain that away? The only thing I can think of as a possible excuse is that the British are too sloppy to do it right.

 
 I don't see that it's something for me to explain. You're the one who has to explain why the US crime rates are so high when other countries manage to have guns and not go nuts. Too sloppy to do what right? You're not very good at explaining yourself.
 
 
And in many instances you've proven that the obvious escapes you.

 
 Such as?
 
 
No I'm simply stating that making something illegal will only benefit criminals, not anyone else.

 
 Which implies that you support legalization of everything. I'm not sure why you carry on down this line. You can't follow the line that laws do no good, and then support the creation of laws to support that what you want. You either want to remove all laws, or you believe that laws perform a purpose. Either is fine, but you can't argue both.
 
 
Petty criminals, drug lords, it really makes no difference because it all boils down to one thing: the criminals are still armed, the innocent people aren't, and your claim is that society is safer with this method of doing things.

 
 I'm saying that British society is safer as it is at the moment. If this inaccuracy is how you understand it, then I can't help. The point is that society is safer when there isn't a large quantity of guns in circulation. 
 
 But think about what you said! Guns are ILLEGAL, thus anyone who obtains one is a CRIMINAL. This means that CRIMINALS ARE THE ONLY ONES WHO CAN HAVE GUNS. Your statement implodes in a circle of fatuous logic.
 
 
I don't care what rank a criminal individual has, they're all the same to me; people who knowingly and willingly break the laws to get ahead through illegal channels. Trying to explain away the differences doesn't fly with me, they're all members of the same society class; criminals. And your statement still amounts to "Criminals have guns, regular people don't, and society is safer this way". 

 
 Ah, you're one of those people! You don't actually bother getting into the guts of a problem, you're just happy to class a group as homogenous even when they aren't. I'll go through this for you....
 
 If you restrict the number of guns, then guns become limited to those who have the money and the power to obtain them. As a rule these people are involved in drugs, or other illegal trades, and as such won't shoot ordinary people wantonly. Hopefully in time guns can be removed from thier hands as well, but to begin with this isn't possible. It also means that this leads to a reduction in guns in the lower eschelons of crime, making people safer.
Ethmi

I vote we pause here for a few minutes to contemplate the massive stupidity of this utterance.

 
 So despite the editorial and the stats, you're somehow correct even though you have no evidence? To put your logic six feet under, there's only one person you have to keep in mind: Al Capone. His illegal alcohol business thrived during the prohibition era.

title: 4Forums.com Political Debates and Polls -  Firearms: cheap, easy to get and on a street near you
